SUMMARY: NESTED | FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD DETAIL: FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD

com.googlecode.prmf.merapi.util
Class Iterators

java.lang.Object
  com.googlecode.prmf.merapi.util.Iterators

public class Iterators
extends Object

Utility methods for manipulating iterators and iterable structures. The ultimate goal is to have an intuitive interface for straightforwardly dealing with all kinds of traversals.

For example, the iterator() method in this class comes in numerous flavors. Its intent is to give the most logical iterator based on the argument(s). The method not only supports "obvious" iterables, such as lists and arrays, but can also be used to iterate over the matching groups of a MatchResult, the nodes in a NodeList, and hopefully (eventually) anything else over which it may be philosophically desirable to iterate. Design pattern addicts rejoice: calling iterator() with no arguments will return a null iterator (not null, silly, just an iterator which has no elements). Similarly, calling it with a single element will return a single element iterator.

In addition to providing a variety of iterators, this class comes with methods for concisely accomplishing some common tasks, such as sorting, filtering, joining multiple iterators, or defining a mapping involving all elements of a traversal. A neat trick is to: 

import static lawu.util.iterator.Iterators.*;
...and then you can map(), grep(), or join() to your heart's desire. You won't win any code brevity contests (this is still Java), but you might make a few Perl hackers smile. (Or maybe you'll just annoy everyone.)

All iterators returned by this class are UniversalIterators, which means that you can use them whether you need an Iterable, a Java iterator, a Gang of Four iterator, or even an Enumeration. Adapter methods are also provided for converting any of these interfaces to UniversalIterators.

Author:
Miorel-Lucian Palii

adapt

public static <T> UniversalIterator<T> adapt(Iterator<T> iterator)
Adapts a Java Iterator to a UniversalIterator. Because Java iterators do not provide a reset()-like method, the returned iterator will not be resettable.

children

public static ReversibleIterator<File> children(File file)
Returns an iterator over the given file's subfiles. A non-directory will not crash this method, it will simply result in an iterator with no elements. The iterator gives files in lexicographical order based on path, in a system-dependent manner (case-sensitive on Windows, case-insensitive on Unix).

Parameters:
file - parent of the nodes over which to iterate
Returns:
a file iterator

chars

public static UniversalIterator<Character> chars(Iterator<? extends CharSequence> sequences)
Returns an iterator over the characters of the specified character sequences. This might be useful in combination with the lines() family of methods because it allows code like chars(lines(System.in)) (assuming you've statically imported the needed methods).

Parameters:
sequences - an iterator of character sequences

a character iterator

tree

public static UniversalIterator<File> tree(File file)
Returns an iterator over all the files in the directory hierarchy with the specified root. That is, this method is similar to the Unix find utility: if the File given to this method is a directory, the returned iterator will recurse through the directory tree in a depth-first manner. If the argument represents a normal file, the iterator will have a single element, the File itself. A file's children will be traversed in lexicographical order based on path, in a system-dependent manner (case-sensitive on Windows, case-insensitive on Unix).

Parameters:
file - root of the directory hierarchy to traverse
Returns:
an iterator over the directory hierarchy

tree

public static UniversalIterator<Node> tree(Node node)
Returns an iterator over all the nodes in the node tree with the specified root.

Parameters:
node - root of the node hierarchy to traverse
Returns:
an iterator over the node hierarchy

map

public static <T,U> UniversalIterator<U> map(Mapper<? super T,? extends U> mapper,
                                             Iterator<? extends T> iterator)
Maps the elements of a traversal using the specified mapping function. The mapping is done lazily, i.e. the backing mapper does not get to see the elements of the mapped traversal until the returned iterator is explicitly asked for an element. Defining a mapping function with side effects might be a bad idea, but if you insist on applying it to all elements without doing anything else, you may find the traverse(Iterator) method of use.

Type Parameters:
T - domain of mapping function (type of the input traversal)
U - range of mapping function (type over which the returned iterator iterates)
Parameters:
mapper - mapping function
iterator - traversal to map
Returns:
an iterator that performs the same traversal as the input but which applies the mapping function to each element before returning it

filter

public static <T> UniversalIterator<T> filter(Filter<? super T> filter,
                                              Iterator<? extends T> iterator)
Keeps only those elements of a traversal which pass the specified filter.

Type Parameters:
T - type over which the returned iterator iterates
Parameters:
filter - the filtering method
iterator - the traversal to filter
Returns:
an iterator that gives only those elements of the input which pass the specified filter
See Also:
grep(Filter, Iterator)

grep

public static <T> UniversalIterator<T> grep(Filter<? super T> filter,
                                            Iterator<? extends T> iterator)
Unix-esque synonym for filter(Filter,Iterator).

Type Parameters:
T - type over which the returned iterator iterates
Parameters:
filter - the filtering method
iterator - the traversal to filter
Returns:
an iterator that gives only those elements of the input which pass the specified filter

sort

public static <T extends Comparable<T>> UniversalIterator<T> sort(Iterator<? extends T> iterator)
Orders a traversal using the default comparison method.

Type Parameters:
T - type over which the iteration takes place
Parameters:
iterator - the traversal to sort
Returns:
an iterator which gives the same elements as the input but sorted in order according to the default comparison method of the input type
See Also:
sort(Comparator,Iterator)

                                                Random rnd)

T - type over which the iteration takes place
Parameters:
iterator - the traversal to permute

Returns:
an iterator which gives the same elements as the input but randomly permuted

shuffle

public static <T> ReversibleIterator<T> shuffle(Iterator<? extends T> iterator)
Randomly permutes the elements of a traversal. This method is equivalent to calling Iterators.shuffle(iterator, null).

Type Parameters:
T - type over which the iteration takes place
Parameters:
iterator - the traversal to permute
Returns:
an iterator which gives the same elements as the input but randomly permuted

Returns a list containing the elements of an iterator.

Type Parameters:
T - type over which the iteration takes place
Parameters:
iterator - the iterator to transform to a list
Returns:
a list containing the same elements as the iterator

copy

public static <T> ReversibleIterator<T> copy(Iterator<? extends T> iterator)
Returns a copy of the given iterator, that is, another iterator containing the same elements. This is useful if you have an iterator that's backed by another structure (e.g. a list) that might be modified while the iterator is in existence. Note that this method requires traversing the input.

Type Parameters:
T - type over which the iteration takes place
Parameters:
iterator - the iterator to copy
Returns:
an iterator containing the same elements as the input

loop

public static <T> UniversalIterator<T> loop(Iterator<T> iterator)
Returns an iterator that continuously loops over the elements of a traversal. This does not immediately traverse the elements of the input, so it's safe to call with never-ending iterators (though it would serve no purpose).

Type Parameters:
T - type over which the iteration takes place
Parameters:
iterator - the iterator to traverse
Returns:
an iterator that continuously loops over the elements of the input

traverse

public static void traverse(Iterator<?> iterator)
Traverses all the elements of an iterator from the beginning, doing nothing. This might be useful for forcing evaluation of lazy methods, such as map(Mapper,Iterator).

Parameters:
iterator - the iterator to traverse

reverse

public static <T> ReversibleIterator<T> reverse(Iterator<T> iterator)
Reverses a traversal. Note that this will probably require actually going through the entire traversal, so avoid calling with never-ending iterators unless you like infinite loops.

Type Parameters:
T - type over which the iteration takes place
Parameters:
iterator - the traversal to reverse
Returns:
an iterator which gives the same elements as the input but in reverse order
